description: From Middle English fese, from the verb (see below).

entries.meaning: (obsolete or US, dialectal) A state of fretful excitement or worry.
(obsolete) A rush, impetus, or violent movement.
(obsolete) A running start or run-up, as for a leap; used in the expression "to fetch one's feeze".
(obsolete, Scotland) A device for wedging items into a tight space.

description: From Middle English fesen, from Old English fēsian, fȳsian (“to drive away, put to flight”), variants of fēsan, fȳsan (“to hasten, rush; to incite, stimulate, send forth, drive away”), of disputed origin. Doublet of faze.

verbs.description: feeze (third-person singular simple present feezes, present participle feezing, simple past and past participle feezed) (obsolete or dialectal)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To drive off, frighten away, or cause to flee or hesitate; to faze.

examples: He had not been squelched. he had not been feased by the feigned rebuke of the Hon. John Masterson McInnery.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To swing about or flare (as a candle).
(intransitive) To fret; be in a fume; worry.
examples: he just did an honest day's work, each day, without worrying and "feezing" about the winter.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To hurry; to move in an agitated manner.

description: From Scots feeze, from Old Scots fize (“screw”, noun), from Dutch vijs (“screw”), from Middle Dutch vise (“screw, windlass, winch”), from Old French vis, viz (“vise, vice”), from Latin vītis (“vine”). Doublet of vice, vise, and withe.

verbs.description: feeze (third-person singular simple present feezes, present participle feezing, simple past and past participle feezed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Scotland) To screw; twist; tighten or loosen by screwing.
(transitive, intransitive, Scotland) To untwist; to unravel, as the end of a rope.

verbs.description: feeze (third-person singular simple present feezes, present participle feezing, simple past and past participle foze)
